<p><strong>I search my name on a regular basis,</strong> not only because I am an ego monster (although I try not to pretend that I’m not) but because it’s a good way for me to find reviews, end-of-the-year “best of” lists my book might be on, foreign publication release dates, and other information about my work that I might not otherwise see, and which is useful for me to keep tabs on. In one of those searches I found that Grok (the “AI” of X) attributed to one of my books (<em>The Consuming Fire</em>) a dedication I did not write; not only have I definitively never dedicated a book to the characters of <em>Frozen</em>, I also do not have multiple children, just the one.</p>



<p>Why did Grok misattribute the quote? Well, because nearly all consumer-facing “AI” are essentially “fancy autocomplete,” designed to find the next likely word rather than offer factual accuracy. “AI” is not actually either intelligent or conscious, and doesn’t know when it’s offering bad information, it just runs its processes and gives a statistically likely answer, which is very likely to be factually wrong. “Statistically likely” does not equal “correct.”</p>



<p>Still, I was curious who other “AI” would tell me I had dedicated<em> The Consuming Fire</em> to. So I asked. Here’s the answer Google gave me in its search page “AI Overview”:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" decoding="async" width="639" height="289" data-attachment-id="58651" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-092722/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?fit=1023%2C463&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1023,463" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 092722" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?fit=300%2C136&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?fit=1023%2C463&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?resize=639%2C289&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58651" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?w=1023&ssl=1 1023w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?resize=300%2C136&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-092722.jpg?resize=768%2C348&ssl=1 768w" sizes="(max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>I do have a daughter, but she would be very surprised to learn that after nearly 27 years of being called “Athena,” that her name was “Corbin.” I mean, Krissy and I enjoy <em>The Fifth Element</em>, but not that much. Also I did not dedicate the book to my daughter, under any name.</p>



<p>Here’s Copilot, Microsoft’s “AI”:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="525" height="363" data-attachment-id="58653" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-093140/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?fit=525%2C363&ssl=1" data-orig-size="525,363" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 093140" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?fit=300%2C207&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?fit=525%2C363&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?resize=525%2C363&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58653" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?w=525&ssl=1 525w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-093140.jpg?resize=300%2C207&ssl=1 300w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 525px) 100vw, 525px" /></figure>



<p>I have indeed dedicated (or co-dedicated) several books to Krissy, and I’m glad that Copilot did not believe that my spouse’s name was “Leloo.” But in fact I did not dedicate <em>The Consuming Fire</em> to Krissy. </p>



<p>How did ChatGPT fare? Poorly:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="335" data-attachment-id="58655" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-094027/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?fit=1050%2C550&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1050,550" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 094027" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?fit=300%2C157&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?fit=1050%2C550&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?resize=639%2C335&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58655" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?w=1050&ssl=1 1050w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?resize=300%2C157&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-094027.jpg?resize=768%2C402&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>I know at least a couple of people named Corey, and a couple named Cory, but I didn’t dedicate <em>The Consuming Fire</em> to any of them. Also, note that ChatGPT not only misattributed to whom I dedicated the book,<em> it also entirely fabricated the dedication itself</em>. I didn’t ask for the text of the dedication, so ChatGPT voluntarily went out of its way to add extra erroneous information to the mix. Which is… a choice!</p>



<p>I also asked Claude, the “AI” of Anthropic, and to its (and/or Anthropic’s) credit, it was the only “AI” of the batch which did not confidently squirt out an incorrect answer. It admitted it did not have reliable search information on the answer and undertook a few web searches to try to find the information, and eventually told me it could not find it, offering advice instead on how I could find the information myself (for the record, you <em>can</em> find the information online; I did by going to Amazon and searching the excerpt there). So good on Claude for knowing what it doesn’t know and admitting it. </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="835" data-attachment-id="58660" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-111653/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?fit=1137%2C1485&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1137,1485" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 111653" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?fit=230%2C300&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?fit=1137%2C1485&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?resize=639%2C835&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58660" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?w=1137&ssl=1 1137w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?resize=230%2C300&ssl=1 230w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-111653.jpg?resize=768%2C1003&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>Interestingly, when I went to Grok directly and asked to whom the book was dedicated, it also said it couldn’t find that information. When I asked it why a different instance of itself incorrectly attributed a different dedication to the book, it more or less shrugged and said what I found to be the equivalent of “dude, it happens.” I also checked Gemini directly (which as I understand it powers Google’s Search “AI” Overview) to see if it would also say “I can’t find that information.” Nope: </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="220" data-attachment-id="58658" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-105848/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?fit=1173%2C403&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1173,403" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 105848" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?fit=300%2C103&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?fit=1173%2C403&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?resize=639%2C220&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58658" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?w=1173&ssl=1 1173w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?resize=300%2C103&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-105848.jpg?resize=768%2C264&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>I’m sure this comes as a surprise to both Ms. Rusch and Mr. Smith, who are (at least on my side) collegial acquaintances but not people I would dedicate a book to. And indeed I did not. When I informed Gemini it had gotten it wrong, it apologized, misattributed <em>The Consuming Fire</em> to another author (C. Robert Cargill, who writes great stuff, just not this), and suggested that he dedicated the book to his wife (he did not) and that her name was “Carly” (it is not). </p>



<p>(I also informed Copilot that it had gotten the dedication wrong, and it also tried again, asserting I dedicated it to Athena. I’m glad Copilot got the name of my kid right, but as previously stated, <em>The Consuming Fire</em> is not dedicated to her.)</p>



<p>So: Five different “AI” and two iterations of two of them, and only Claude would not, at any point, offer up incorrect information about the dedication in <em>The Consuming Fire</em>. Which I will note does not get Claude off the hook for hallucinating information. It has done so before when I’ve queried it about things relating to me, and I’m pretty confident I can get it to do it again. But in this one instance, it did not. </p>



<p>None of them, not even Claude, got the information correct (which is different from “offered up incorrect information”). Two of them, when informed they were incorrect, “corrected” by offering even more incorrect information. </p>



<p>I’ve said this before and I will say it again: I ask “AI” things about me all the time, because I know what the actual answer is, and “AI” will consistently and confidently get those things wrong. If I can’t trust it to get right the things I know, I cannot trust it to get right the things I do not know. </p>



<p>Just to make sure this confident misstating of dedication facts was not personal, I picked a random book not by me off my shelf and asked Gemini (which was still open in my browser) to name to whom the book was dedicated.</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="309" data-attachment-id="58662" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-112556/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?fit=1174%2C568&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1174,568" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 112556" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?fit=300%2C145&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?fit=1174%2C568&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?resize=639%2C309&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58662" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?w=1174&ssl=1 1174w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?resize=300%2C145&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-112556.jpg?resize=768%2C372&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>It certainly feels like Richard Kadrey <em>might </em>dedicate a book in the Sandman Slim series to the lead singer of The Cramps, but in fact <em>Aloha From Hell </em>is not dedicated to him. </p>



<p>Let’s try another: </p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="235" data-attachment-id="58664" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-113915/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?fit=1156%2C426&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1156,426" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 113915" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?fit=300%2C111&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?fit=1156%2C426&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?resize=639%2C235&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58664" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?w=1156&ssl=1 1156w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?resize=300%2C111&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-113915.jpg?resize=768%2C283&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>Daniel H. Wilson’s <em>Robopocalypse </em>may be dedicated to his wife, but if it is, her name is not “Kellie,” as that is not the name in the dedication. </p>



<p>Let’s see if the third time’s the charm:</p>



<figure class="wp-block-image size-full has-custom-border"><img data-recalc-dims="1" loading="lazy" decoding="async" width="639" height="218" data-attachment-id="58666" data-permalink="https://whatever.scalzi.com/2025/12/13/ai-a-dedicated-fact-failing-machine-or-yet-another-reason-not-to-trust-it-for-anything/screenshot-2025-12-13-114248/" data-orig-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?fit=1156%2C394&ssl=1" data-orig-size="1156,394" data-comments-opened="1" data-image-meta="{"aperture":"0","credit":"","camera":"","caption":"","created_timestamp":"0","copyright":"","focal_length":"0","iso":"0","shutter_speed":"0","title":"","orientation":"0"}" data-image-title="Screenshot 2025-12-13 114248" data-image-description="" data-image-caption="" data-medium-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?fit=300%2C102&ssl=1" data-large-file="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?fit=1156%2C394&ssl=1" src="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?resize=639%2C218&ssl=1" alt="" class="has-border-color has-000000-border-color wp-image-58666" srcset="https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?w=1156&ssl=1 1156w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?resize=300%2C102&ssl=1 300w, https://i0.wp.com/whatever.scalzi.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/12/Screenshot-2025-12-13-114248.jpg?resize=768%2C262&ssl=1 768w" sizes="auto, (max-width: 639px) 100vw, 639px" /></figure>



<p>It’s more accurate to say this was a third strike for Gemini, as G. Willow Wilson did not dedicate <em>Alif the Unseen</em> to a Hasan, choosing instead her daughter, whose name that is not. </p>



<p>So it’s not just me, “AI” gets other book dedications wrong, and (at least here) consistently so. These book dedications are <em>actual known facts</em> anyone can ascertain — you can literally just crack open a book to see to whom a book is dedicated — and these facts are being gotten wrong, consistently and repeatedly, by “AI.” Again, think about all the things “AI” could be getting wrong that you won’t have such wherewithal to check.</p>



<p>What do we learn from this?</p>



<p><strong>One: </strong>Don’t use “AI” as a search engine. You’ll get bad information and you might not even know.</p>



<p><strong>Two:</strong> Don’t trust “AI” to offer you facts. When it doesn’t know something, it will frequently offer you confidently-stated incorrect information, because it’s a statistical engine, not a fact-checker. </p>



<p><strong>Three:</strong> Inasmuch as you are going to have to double-check every “fact” that “AI”” provides to you, why not eliminate the middleman and just <em>not </em>use “AI”? It’s not decreasing your workload here, it’s adding to it.</p>



<p>Does “AI” have uses? Possibly, just not this. I don’t blame “AI” for any of this, it’s not those programs’ fault that the people who own and market them <em>and know they are statistical matching engines</em> willfully and, bluntly, deceitfully position them to be other things. You don’t blame an electric bread maker when some fool declares that it’s an excellent air filter. But you shouldn’t use it as an air filter, no matter how many billions of dollars are being spent to convince you of its air-filtering acumen. Use an actual air filter, damn it.</p>



<p>I dedicate this essay to everyone out there who will take these lessons to heart and not trust “AI” to tell you things. You are the real ones. And that’s a fact.</p>



<p>— JS</p>

					<div class="comment-content">
												<p>It’s becoming clear that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman’s Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine. Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language. A machine with only primary consciousness will probably have to come first.</p>
<p>What I find special about the TNGS is the Darwin series of automata created at the Neurosciences Institute by Dr. Edelman and his colleagues in the 1990’s and 2000’s. These machines perform in the real world, not in a restricted simulated world, and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness, such as perceptual categorization, memory, and learning. They are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions. The extended TNGS allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions, in a parsimonious way. No other research I’ve encountered is anywhere near as convincing.</p>
<p>I post because on almost every video and article about the brain and consciousness that I encounter, the attitude seems to be that we still know next to nothing about how the brain and consciousness work; that there’s lots of data but no unifying theory. I believe the extended TNGS is that theory. My motivation is to keep that theory in front of the public. And obviously, I consider it the route to a truly conscious machine, primary and higher-order.</p>
<p>My advice to people who want to create a conscious machine is to seriously ground themselves in the extended TNGS and the Darwin automata first, and proceed from there, by applying to Jeff Krichmar’s lab at UC Irvine, possibly. Dr. Edelman’s roadmap to a conscious machine is at <a href="https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.10461" rel="nofollow ugc">https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.10461</a>, and here is a video of Jeff Krichmar talking about some of the Darwin automata, <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J7Uh9phc1Ow" rel="nofollow ugc">https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=J7Uh9phc1Ow</a></p>

					<div class="comment-content">
												<p>Dear Mr. Scalzi:<br />
I am a software engineer who got his start in programming at a place called SAIL (the Stanford Artificial Intelligence Laboratory) and SLAC (the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center).  I earned a bachelor’s degree in computer science and mathematics, and a master’s degree, both at UC Berkeley.  I have been earning a living as a software engineer since then (admittedly, in real-time embedded software development rather than AI, but I still read journals).</p>
<p>The current LLMs (large language model AIs) are, in my not-so-humble opinion, another “silver bullet” and something of a waste of time.  This is not only my opinion – it appears that one of the “founding fathers” of modern AI has been saying the same thing that I have been saying – that the LLM approach is not going in the right direction to produce artificial general intelligence (as in, “human variety intelligence”), link to follow:<br />
<a href="https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/meta-top-ai-scientist-quitting?utm_source=beehiiv&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=futurism-newsletter&_bhlid=9fe75ff446705a20f2213c558d79f73181b7667a" rel="nofollow ugc">https://futurism.com/artificial-intelligence/meta-top-ai-scientist-quitting?utm_source=beehiiv&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=futurism-newsletter&_bhlid=9fe75ff446705a20f2213c558d79f73181b7667a</a></p>
<p>Right now, LLMs are autocorrect systems on steroids that base their predictions on the massive data mining (read: “plagiarism”) used to train them.  And they have all been demonstrated to frequently hallucinate (read: “make things up out of whole cloth”).  While some of their hallucinations can be mildly entertaining, they are ruining previously useful applications.  Case in point?  Google maps, which I used to rely upon for GPS navigation in Los Angeles; since Google added their AI functionality, I have found it has developed a tendency to send me “all round Robin Hood’s barn” to get to my destinations … on those few times when I have trusted it to give me directions of late.</p>
<p>Sincerely,</p>
<p>Niall Shapero</p>

												<p>The amazing thing about LLMs is that they are capable of generating idiomatic English sentences and coherent paragraphs–something that many my composition students couldn’t do reliably. Nearly 50 years ago one of my colleagues was a linguist who had worked on an Air Force-sponsored machine translation project, and he spoke of the difficulty of that job. Now Google Translate is, from what I hear, pretty good.</p>
<p>On the other hand, during my business-IT journalism days, I got an assignment to survey “taxonomies,” which were at the heart of attempts to optimize search engines by constructing smarter, specialized algorithms–so that, say, pharmaceutical companies could survey large, unstructured sets of research documents in the hope of discovering previously unnoticed connections. They were monstrously powerful statistical engines, and at the heart of each were sets of rules and training documents constructed and vetted by human subject-matter experts. Even at that nosebleed level of computational tech, GIGO still applied. Niall Shapero’s post above confirms what I learned 25 years ago.</p>
<p>To me it looks like the amateur-hour factual errors and misattributions from the likes of ChatGPT are the result of 1) indiscriminate scraping of the entire internet, warts and bullshit and all, and 2) the lack of sufficient human intervention in and  tuning of that vast and error-riddled “training set.” Right now ChatPT et al. strike me as being like the students who <em>had</em> learned how to compose a five-paragraph essay but couldn’t be bothered to do decent library research. (I spent 20 years reading that stuff–believe me, the comparison is apt.)</p>

												<p>I have chatGPT setup to always verify its answers and never invent new information. I’d say it usually works. But sometimes, the verifications provided just don’t exist.<br />

					</footer>

					<div class="comment-content">
												<p>I think one of the things we really need to do is what John does above – either refer to it as an LLM or “AI” with quotes – to indicate it is NOT artificial intelligence, as it is not. It’s a predictive algorithm with a fancy front-end. The front-end plays to people’s desire to see it as a HAL 9000 – an actual reasoning intelligence, rather than updating of the ELIZA program that it is. It is a brilliant marketing move, as it creates a narrative and the chat interface carries the pretense. LLMs don’t think – they don’t analyze – and in many cases they do a far inferior job to well-crafted database searches. LLMs trained on small datasets can be really useful – but again, is it more efficient than an optimized SQL database at scale? LLMs proposal as a soup-to-nuts for all your data needs (in part because training it more specifically would be TOO MUCH WORK) is the big lie, here.</p>

readabilityObject.title: “AI”: A Dedicated Fact-Failing Machine, or, Yet Another Reason Not to Trust It For Anything
readabilityObject.content:
Posted on December 13, 2025    Posted by      77 Comments

I search my name on a regular basis, not only because I am an ego monster (although I try not to pretend that I’m not) but because it’s a good way for me to find reviews, end-of-the-year “best of” lists my book might be on, foreign publication release dates, and other information about my work that I might not otherwise see, and which is useful for me to keep tabs on. In one of those searches I found that Grok (the “AI” of X) attributed to one of my books (The Consuming Fire) a dedication I did not write; not only have I definitively never dedicated a book to the characters of Frozen, I also do not have multiple children, just the one.

Why did Grok misattribute the quote? Well, because nearly all consumer-facing “AI” are essentially “fancy autocomplete,” designed to find the next likely word rather than offer factual accuracy. “AI” is not actually either intelligent or conscious, and doesn’t know when it’s offering bad information, it just runs its processes and gives a statistically likely answer, which is very likely to be factually wrong. “Statistically likely” does not equal “correct.”

Still, I was curious who other “AI” would tell me I had dedicated The Consuming Fire to. So I asked. Here’s the answer Google gave me in its search page “AI Overview”:

I do have a daughter, but she would be very surprised to learn that after nearly 27 years of being called “Athena,” that her name was “Corbin.” I mean, Krissy and I enjoy The Fifth Element, but not that much. Also I did not dedicate the book to my daughter, under any name.

Here’s Copilot, Microsoft’s “AI”:

I have indeed dedicated (or co-dedicated) several books to Krissy, and I’m glad that Copilot did not believe that my spouse’s name was “Leloo.” But in fact I did not dedicate The Consuming Fire to Krissy.

How did ChatGPT fare? Poorly:

I know at least a couple of people named Corey, and a couple named Cory, but I didn’t dedicate The Consuming Fire to any of them. Also, note that ChatGPT not only misattributed to whom I dedicated the book, it also entirely fabricated the dedication itself. I didn’t ask for the text of the dedication, so ChatGPT voluntarily went out of its way to add extra erroneous information to the mix. Which is… a choice!

I also asked Claude, the “AI” of Anthropic, and to its (and/or Anthropic’s) credit, it was the only “AI” of the batch which did not confidently squirt out an incorrect answer. It admitted it did not have reliable search information on the answer and undertook a few web searches to try to find the information, and eventually told me it could not find it, offering advice instead on how I could find the information myself (for the record, you can find the information online; I did by going to Amazon and searching the excerpt there). So good on Claude for knowing what it doesn’t know and admitting it.

Interestingly, when I went to Grok directly and asked to whom the book was dedicated, it also said it couldn’t find that information. When I asked it why a different instance of itself incorrectly attributed a different dedication to the book, it more or less shrugged and said what I found to be the equivalent of “dude, it happens.” I also checked Gemini directly (which as I understand it powers Google’s Search “AI” Overview) to see if it would also say “I can’t find that information.” Nope:

I’m sure this comes as a surprise to both Ms. Rusch and Mr. Smith, who are (at least on my side) collegial acquaintances but not people I would dedicate a book to. And indeed I did not. When I informed Gemini it had gotten it wrong, it apologized, misattributed The Consuming Fire to another author (C. Robert Cargill, who writes great stuff, just not this), and suggested that he dedicated the book to his wife (he did not) and that her name was “Carly” (it is not).

(I also informed Copilot that it had gotten the dedication wrong, and it also tried again, asserting I dedicated it to Athena. I’m glad Copilot got the name of my kid right, but as previously stated, The Consuming Fire is not dedicated to her.)

None of them, not even Claude, got the information correct (which is different from “offered up incorrect information”). Two of them, when informed they were incorrect, “corrected” by offering even more incorrect information.

If I can’t trust it to get right the things I know, I cannot trust it to get right the things I do not know.

Just to make sure this confident misstating of dedication facts was not personal, I picked a random book not by me off my shelf and asked Gemini (which was still open in my browser) to name to whom the book was dedicated.

It certainly feels like Richard Kadrey might dedicate a book in the Sandman Slim series to the lead singer of The Cramps, but in fact Aloha From Hell is not dedicated to him.

Let’s try another:

Daniel H. Wilson’s Robopocalypse may be dedicated to his wife, but if it is, her name is not “Kellie,” as that is not the name in the dedication.

Let’s see if the third time’s the charm:

It’s more accurate to say this was a third strike for Gemini, as G. Willow Wilson did not dedicate Alif the Unseen to a Hasan, choosing instead her daughter, whose name that is not.

So it’s not just me, “AI” gets other book dedications wrong, and (at least here) consistently so. These book dedications are actual known facts anyone can ascertain — you can literally just crack open a book to see to whom a book is dedicated — and these facts are being gotten wrong, consistently and repeatedly, by “AI.” Again, think about all the things “AI” could be getting wrong that you won’t have such wherewithal to check.

What do we learn from this?

One: Don’t use “AI” as a search engine. You’ll get bad information and you might not even know.

Two: Don’t trust “AI” to offer you facts. When it doesn’t know something, it will frequently offer you confidently-stated incorrect information, because it’s a statistical engine, not a fact-checker.

Three: Inasmuch as you are going to have to double-check every “fact” that “AI”” provides to you, why not eliminate the middleman and just not use “AI”? It’s not decreasing your workload here, it’s adding to it.

Does “AI” have uses? Possibly, just not this. I don’t blame “AI” for any of this, it’s not those programs’ fault that the people who own and market them and know they are statistical matching engines willfully and, bluntly, deceitfully position them to be other things. You don’t blame an electric bread maker when some fool declares that it’s an excellent air filter. But you shouldn’t use it as an air filter, no matter how many billions of dollars are being spent to convince you of its air-filtering acumen. Use an actual air filter, damn it.

I dedicate this essay to everyone out there who will take these lessons to heart and not trust “AI” to tell you things. You are the real ones. And that’s a fact.

— JS
